claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions, computers, and smartphones has decreased significantly since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.

attacks.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions, computers, and smartphones has decreased significantly since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.
While average prices have decreased, inflation-adjusted costs may not show the same level of affordability, especially for high-end electronics.
Inflation-adjusted data still shows a significant decline in prices for most consumer electronics, even for high-end models, when accounting for technological improvements.
The decrease in prices is offset by planned obsolescence, leading consumers to replace electronics more frequently, increasing long-term costs.
Planned obsolescence affects some products, but many electronics now have longer lifespans and better warranties, mitigating this issue.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that the cost of electronic devices like laptops and mobile phones has declined over the past three decades, making them more accessible to the general population.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that the cost of electronic devices like laptops and mobile phones has declined over the past three decades, making them more accessible to the general population.
While average prices have declined, high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones, premium laptops) have seen price increases, skewing affordability for certain segments.
Even high-end electronics offer more features per dollar than in 1990, maintaining relative affordability despite nominal price increases.
The data ignores hidden costs like mandatory subscriptions, accessories, or planned obsolescence that increase total ownership costs.
Studies show total cost of ownership has still decreased when accounting for inflation and increased utility per dollar spent.

supporting.text: The proliferation of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down prices for electronics in the US since 1990.

attacks.text: The proliferation of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down prices for electronics in the US since 1990.
While competition has increased, rising costs of raw materials and tariffs have offset price reductions in electronics.
The impact of tariffs and raw material costs is minimal compared to the efficiency gains from global supply chains.
Inflation-adjusted prices for many electronics have remained stable or increased due to premium features and branding.
Basic electronics without premium features have seen significant price drops, making them more accessible.

supporting.text: Technological advancements have reduced production costs for electronic components, leading to lower retail prices for end consumers in the US.

attacks.text: Technological advancements have reduced production costs for electronic components, leading to lower retail prices for end consumers in the US.
Inflation-adjusted prices for some high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones, GPUs) have actually increased due to premium features and market segmentation.
Even high-end electronics offer significantly better performance per dollar than 1990s equivalents when accounting for technological capabilities.
Supply chain disruptions (e.g., semiconductor shortages) have caused price spikes in recent years, temporarily reversing long-term affordability trends.
These disruptions are transient market corrections that don't negate the decades-long deflationary trend in electronics pricing.

supporting.text: The introduction of budget-friendly electronic brands and models has expanded the market, offering more affordable options compared to 1990.

attacks.text: The introduction of budget-friendly electronic brands and models has expanded the market, offering more affordable options compared to 1990.
While budget-friendly options exist, inflation-adjusted prices for high-end electronics have increased, offsetting affordability gains.
High-end electronics represent a small segment of the market, and most consumers benefit from the broader affordability of mid-range and budget options.
The rise in disposable income since 1990 means affordability improvements may not be solely due to lower prices but also higher purchasing power.
Even accounting for higher disposable income, the real price decline in electronics (e.g., TVs, smartphones) still demonstrates increased affordability.

supporting.text: Government policies and trade agreements have reduced tariffs on electronic imports, contributing to lower prices for consumers in the US since 1990.

attacks.text: Government policies and trade agreements have reduced tariffs on electronic imports, contributing to lower prices for consumers in the US since 1990.
While tariffs may have decreased, other costs such as supply chain disruptions and inflation have offset these savings, keeping prices stable or higher.
Supply chain disruptions and inflation are temporary factors, whereas tariff reductions have a long-term structural impact on prices.
Many electronics are now produced domestically or in countries not covered by these trade agreements, limiting the impact of tariff reductions.
Even domestically produced electronics rely on imported components, so tariff reductions still contribute to lower overall production costs.
